Actual saperenode implementation

The aim of this document is collecting information about the actual version of SAPEREnode, developed by Michele Desanti (see his thesis page ) and Michele Morgagni (see his thesis page ).

All information presented in this section will be used as a starting point for this thesis work.

The Node

A SAPERE node, according to the resulting implementation, is composed by:

  • a Space which provides a mean of serialization for local LSAs (see The space subsection)
  • a Reaction Manager which is an entity responsible of handling and scheduling operations (on the space) that affect the current state of the node (see The Reaction Manager subsection)
  • a Notifier which alerts subscribers of relevant events
  • a set of Agents and Managers which handles networking and interactions with other nodes and entities outside the system

Space and ReactionManager are the most important components of this architecture because they're involved in system status management . Considering that this project needs to act on this component they will be presented deeply in the following.

The Space

The space is defined as an entity capable of:

  • Having a name
  • Providing agents primitives: inject , remove , update , read (no observation primitive)
  • Providing support to transactions
  • Providing fresh LSA ids
  • Providing a way to retrieve all LSAs or all LSA ids

An LSA is defined as the composition of an ID and a Content (a.k.a. Semantic Description). A Semantic Description is a set of Properties, each one defined by a name and a set of values: if number sign (" # ") is prefixed to the name the property is called a synthetic property, which is a read-only property that only the middleware can update; no other constraint has been set.

The Reaction Manager

In this implementation the reaction manager is the entity responsible for interaction with the space and scheduling of reactions.

After its creation some ecolaws can be added. Moreover only queueOperation or queueTransaction can be called in order to inform the manager of the intention to execute some sort of operation(s). Operations requested by the user or by the execution of an ecolaw are scheduled according to local time. An ecolaw is fired exploiting the ReagentMatcher : for each ecolaw a score is computed in order to determine if its reactants exist; in this case a transaction (which will update the LSA-space) is scheduled for the next rate occurrence.
